text.intro:
Greyforge, the mountain city in the north of the Kaldarian lands is home to the proud dwarves who settled in the area over 8,000 years ago, led by a silver dragon, according to some stories.
Famous for their expertise in crafting and artifice, the Greyforge dwarves use giant lava powered furnaces, deep underground, to process the toughest metals.
Scholars and mages travel here from all over the continent in search of ancient lore in the dusty tomes of the Greyforge library, which is famed as the largest library in all Aradia.
Most of the city lies safely under the surface of the mountain making it easily defensible. A strong military force is ready to defend the city at all times from threats of goblinoid clans vying for control of the natural resources of the area and hungry herds of monstrous beasts.
Queen Mabaegar Thunderarmour is the recently appointed Queen after her predecessor was found dead under mysterious circumstances. Young but wise, she seeks advice from the older members of the Council of Twelve. She is honest and honourable and wants the best for her people.
Apart from dwarves, many other ancestries call Greyforge home: humans, gnomes, halflings, tieflings and dragonborn.
More than anything, Greyforge is your home. You spend your whole life in the sheltered walls of the great stone city. Today, a day like any other, you are summoned by Corvus Stouthammer, proprietor of the Stout Meal Inn, one of the oldest establishments in the city. He said he has a quick job for you.

conclusion.good_ending: Well done! You discovered the secret tomb underneath the Stout Meal Inn.
conclusion.bad_ending: You never discovered the secret underneath the Stout Meal Inn...

corvus.name: Corvus
corvus.description: The wrinkly whitebearded dwarf proprietor of the Stout Meal Inn.

dialogue.gives_quest: He says: "Could you check out the cellar, we seem to be having a rat problem. My cat, Anvil-jumper, ventured in there yesterday and hasn't been seen since. There's a little silver in it for you of course! What do you say, do you accept the quest?"
dialogue.payment: He says: "10 silver pieces per rat."
dialogue.good_negotiation: He lets out a gentle chuckle and says: "Well go on then, seeing as we're old friends, 20 silver pieces per rat!"
dialogue.bad_negotiation: He looks at you with narrowing eyes and says: "I don't think so friend, 10 silver pieces per rat is more than fair.""
dialogue.accepts_quest: He says: "Cheers to that! I knew you'd help me out, you can get to the cellar by going downstairs, through the door behind the bar."
dialogue.turns_down_quest: He says: "That's a shame, I'll just have to clear out the rats myself...". After exchanging a few pleasantries, you leave the Stout Meal Inn leaving Corvus to investigate the cellar alone. He is mortally wounded by a giant rat after trying to rescue Anvil-Jumper from the monster.
dialogue.turn_in_quest: You tell Corvus the good news about clearing out the giant rats. You share a drink together and then take your leave, with a slightly heavier coin purse. Some time later a couple of goblins creep up from the cellar. They catch Corvus unawares and murder him. If only you'd investigated the tunnel in the cellar you could have killed the goblins before they got Corvus!

text.enter: On this particularly cold morning you find yourself at the Stout Meal Inn, a fine establishment known for it's fantastic ales. This tavern is very large, with a long central hearth that helps to keep the cold at bay against the thick stone walls. Bundles of herbs dangle from the wooden rafters, filling the space with a plethora of fragrant aromas. The tavern floor is empty apart from a lone figure. Corvus Stouthammer, the wrinkly whitebearded dwarf proprietor prepares the inn for the day's patrons, polishing the top of a nearby table to a brilliant sheen. There is a doorway down to the cellar behind the bar. As you come closer Corvus' attention comes to you and he stops polishing. He turns to you with a slight smile under his beard and welcomes you, saying: "About time you showed up!"
text.description: Homely tavern with a few tables, a well stocked bar and a whitebearded dwarf preparing the room for the day's visitors.
text.no_visibility_description: Homely tavern with a few tables, a well stocked bar and a whitebearded dwarf preparing the room for the day's visitors.

text.enter: You descend into the dark and damp cellar of the inn. The light from the ground floor above dimly illuminates the landing but the rest of the cellar is covered in complete darkness. The landing in front of you leads left into the main cellar where you can hear the squeaks of rats as they destroy Corvus' stock and the loud protesting meows of Anvil-Jumper, Corvus' cat.
text.visibility: You see a terrible scene in front of you. Anvil-Jumper the cat is sitting on top of one of the barrels in the north-east corner of the room, meowing pathetically at the giant rats who are entirely indifferent to his plight. There are two giant rats in the cellar tearing through the food supplies. The rats have burst through a 5 ft by 5 ft hole in the eastern wall of the cellar.
text.no_visibility_description: The room is too dark to see anything.
text.fight_ends: You vanquished the giant rats! With a swish of his tail, Anvil-Jumper leaps from the barrel and dashes upstairs. Corvus will be pleased, if you choose you can return to him to receive your handsome reward. It may be worth investigating this room further to see if you find anything of value. You may also want to determine what caused the giant rats to come here, there may be something to investigate in the storage room accessible through the hole in the eastern wall.

attack.say: You break the door into a pile of splinters!

str.say: The door gives way after a well placed shoulder barge.

perception.say: You take a closer look around the room and you notice a switch to the left of the portcullis. You press the switch and with a rusty screech the portcullis rises.

text.enter: You crawl into the dark tunnel. Your footsteps echo in its narrow walls as each step crushes the gravel that lines the floor. In the distance you can hear disturbing wet crunching noises. Some 25 feet of a downward squeeze through the narrow dirty passage you emerge in a larger chamber that's not part of the cellar. The air in this area is cold, dry and stale and reeks of death. The architecture of this room is completely different to the cellar of the inn. The walls and floor of this square room are lined with dark gray stone slabs. There are rows of decorative skulls lining the walls 1 foot from the floor and 1 foot from the ceiling. One exit leads to the Burial Chamber and another exit leads to the Western Chamber, but it's blocked by a lowered portcullis. There are stone benches in front of the northern and western walls and instruments of various shapes, sizes and materials are strewn about. The source of the disturbing noises is a zombie hunched over the far corner of the room. A smaller goblin form appears to be lying motionless in front of the hunched one.
text.no_visibility_description: The room is too dark to see anything.
text.fight_ends: You slew the foul zombie! Although it looks like further progress is temporarily blocked by this portcullis. If you're strong enough you could probably force it open or you could look around the room for another solution.

pick_up.say: You examine the closed vault next to this one and think it might be able to be forced open.
You take a look in the open vault and you notice the glint of a silver key in the open vault. You add the key to your inventory.

religion.say: Your religion knowledge allows you to determine the dust covered altar is dedicated to Thorogrin, the patron deity of dwarves, the hammer and anvil being his holy symbol.

text.enter: On the western wall of the room you can see six unmarked stone vault doors. The one furthest from you lies open. On the eastern wall there's a large grinning skull engraved in the centre. On the southern wall there is a ceremonial stone altar decorated with a hammer in front of an anvil.
text.description: You see a ceremonial altar, six unmarked stone vault doors and a large skull engraving.
text.no_visibility_description: The room is too dark to see anything.
text.fight_ends: Phew, that was a close one! It might be worth having a look around the room if you haven't already, but be careful!

text.enter: You make your way deeper into the dungeon, descending down a set of dusty old stone stairs. The steps are cracked but safe enough. Mid-way through your descent you notice a soft cold breeze brushing against your face. The steps end in a 10-feet wide dark corridor. The walls are decorated with pillars in regular intervals on either side. There are sconces with torches on the pillars but they are all unlit. You can see a light in the antechamber at the end of the corridor, some 75-feet away. Most likely torchlight, it is dim and causes the shadows to dance around in the distance. You can hear a quiet conversation between two humanoids echoing beyond the corridor. Whatever creatures await in the antechamber appear to be speaking in hushed voices and it's hard to distinguish what they are saying from here.
text.no_visibility_description: The room is too dark to see anything.

unlock.say: You hear the unlocking mechanism as you twist the key in the lock of the wooden door. With a small push the door swings open.

text.enter: The circular room beyond the corridor has four stone benches against the walls. The floor is decorated with a badly damaged mosaic that has lost most of its original colour and luster. The walls are decorated with intricate painted murals depicting a silver dragon flying over a mountain in a blue sky as different dwarf clans converge toward the mountain. The name "Rizoarithra, Our Protector" is inscribed next to the dragon. There is a wooden door reinforced with iron which leads to the southern corridor. There are two goblins here.
text.description: It's a circular room with an intricate mural of the silver dragon, Rizoarithra.
text.no_visibility_description: The room is too dark to see anything.
text.fight_ends: Well done for vanquishing your foes! Onwards towards the quest's end.

stages.utterance: Speak these names and you shall pass.
I am the father of the children of metal born from the heart of the world. My anvil and hammer a sign for those who craft and learn.

hints.text: You know that "children" of metal is another name for dwarves.
You recognise the reference to the creation myth of the dwarves.
You identify the anvil and hammer as a reference to Thorogrin's holy symbol and divine domains, the forge and knowledge.

stages.utterance: On mighty silver wings I fly, my breath cold as ice. Relics of old and treasures adorn my home. Secret guardian under the mountain.

hints.text: You recognise the references to a silver dragon.
You know that the "secret guardian under the mountain" refers to the founding of Greyforge and the guardian dragon that led the dwarf settlers to the mountain that would become their home.
You remember the myths about Rizoarithra, the silver dragon guardian of Greyforge.

stages.utterance: Name me and so you shall break me.

text.enter: This 40-feet-long corridor appears to end in a dead-end. A large bearded dwarven face has been engraved on the wall to the south.
text.description: It's a corridor with an elaborate dwarven engraving at the end.
text.no_visibility_description: The room is too dark to see anything.

pick_up.say: You take a closer look in the sarcophagus. This must be the final resting place of Baradin Stormfury. You take the warhammer, which you later find out is a priceless, very rare weapon called "Dwarven Thrower". Corvus rejoices at your return and the discovery of this rare dwarven artifact. You share a celebratory ale and claim your reward. It was a great day!

text.enter: This large room is occupied by a single open sarcophagus without a lid. The sarcophagus is tilted upwards at an angle so that its contents are visible as you enter the room. Inside the sarcophagus lie the skeletal remains of a dwarven warrior in a dusty metal armor. The warrior is holding a warhammer. The warhammer's head is made of white stone and framed with gold. An emerald is in the centre of the hammer head. The warhammer appears completely clean and free of dust and cobwebs, almost as if it was placed there moments and not centuries ago. There are dwarven runes inscribed around the perimeter of the sarcophagus, on the along the top of each side. Large iron candle holders sit on either side of the sarcophagus with five melted candles on each. Fire braziers adorn the western and eastern walls of the room. On the southern wall, behind the sarcophagus, there is a large round engraving of a hammer in front of an anvil.
text.description: It's a large room with a single open sarcophagus without a lid.
text.no_visibility_description: The room is too dark to see anything.
